name: Hack the planet
description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

key_work.title: Hacknet
key_work.creator_credit: Fellow Traveller and Team Fractal Alligator
key_work.brief_description: Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

constellations_primary.name: Hack the planet
constellations_primary.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

start.title: ALB - Whispers Under the Moonlight (2014)
start.brief_description: This music video for ALB’s ‘Whispers Under the Moonlight’ claims to be the world’s first ‘Trojan Horse Music Video’. In order to initially play the video and take part, users download a file to their computer which then initiates a series of benign computer takeovers as part of an interactive art installation on the users computer.

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

end.title: Independence Day
end.brief_description: On July 2, a giant alien mothership enters orbit around Earth and deploys several dozen saucer-shaped ‘destroyer’ spacecraft that quickly lay waste to major cities around the planet.

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

links.description: In the memorable ending to Independence Day, the team manage to hack their way into the alien spaceship utilising a Trojan Horse virus â€“ enabling them to save the day.

end.title: Mr. Robot
end.brief_description: A young programmer, Elliot, suffers from a debilitating anti-social disorder and finds himself in the intersection between the cybersecurity firm he works for and the underworld organisations bringing down corporate America.

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

constellations_other.name: Fight for your right
constellations_other.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

constellations_other.name: The power of alternate endings
constellations_other.description: This Constellation about alternate perspectives, dream states, sitcoms and spin-offs was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

constellations_other.name: Freedom from surveillance
constellations_other.description: Real world and cinematic authoritarianism and resistance explored through documentaries, Hollywood blockbusters, TV and videogames.

links.description: Hacknet features gameplay from terminals based on realistic Unix/Linux systems, similar to how much of the accurate hacking is completed in Mr Robot.

end.title: Hackers
end.brief_description: A teenager who was arrested by the US Secret Service and banned from using a computer discovers a plot by a nefarious hacker and breaks the law to stop it.

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

links.description: The season two premiere features a nod to 1995’s Hackers, including a line of source code from real-world hacking tool Social Engineering Program that states ‘Hack the Gibson’, a reference to one of Hackers‘ most infamous scenes.

start.title: Hackers

end.title: WarGames
end.brief_description: David Lightman has a talent for hacking. But while trying to hack into a computer system to play unreleased video games, he unwittingly taps into the Defense Department’s war computer and initiates a confrontation of global proportions!

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

links.description: Hackers features a character known as Phreak, so named from his ability to ‘phreak’ or manipulate landlines. Matthew Broderick’s character in WarGames also phreaks public phone boxes.

In order to initially play the video and take part, users download a file to their computer which then initiates a series of benign computer takeovers as part of an interactive art installation on the users computer.

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

links.description: The music video for ‘Whispers Under the Moonlight’ claims to be the world’s first Trojan Horse music video, a hacking technique used in the game Hacknet. The download file installs photos, emails and wallpapers to the user’s computer as part of an interactive experience.
